definition:
[**Definition.**]{} A square matrix $A$ with complex entries is
*skew-Hermitian*, if $$A^* = -A.$$ Here $A^\ast={\overline{A\dtra}}$,
$A\dtra$ is the transpose of $A$, and ${\overline{A}}$ is is the complex
conjugate of the matrix $A$.

Properties. {#properties. .unnumbered}
-----------

1.  The trace of a skew-Hermitian matrix is .

2.  The eigenvalues of a skew-Hermitian matrix are .

*Proof.* Property (1) follows directly from property (2) since the trace
is the sum of the eigenvalues. But one can also give a simple proof as
follows. Let $x_{ij}$ and $y_{ij}$ be the real respectively imaginary
parts of the elements in $A$. Then the diagonal elements of $A$ are of
the form $x_{kk} + i y_{kk}$, and the diagonal elements in $A^\ast$ are
of the form $-x_{kk} + iy_{kk}$. Hence $x_{kk}$, i.e., the real part for
the diagonal elements in $A$ must vanish, and property (1) follows. For
property (2), suppose $A$ is a skew-Hermitian matrix, and $x$ an
eigenvector corresponding to the eigenvalue $\lambda$, i.e.,
$$\begin{aligned}
\label{gugg}
Ax &=& \lambda x.\end{aligned}$$ Here, $x$ is a complex column vector.
Since $x$ is an eigenvector, $x$ is not the zero vector, and
$x^\ast x > 0$. Without loss of generality we can assume $x^\ast x =1$.
Thus $$\begin{aligned}
{\overline{\lambda}} &=& x^\ast {\overline{\lambda}} x\\
&=& ( x^\ast \lambda x )^\ast \\
&=& (x^\ast A x )^\ast \\
&=& x^\ast A^\ast x \\
&=& x^\ast (-A) x \\
&=& -x^\ast \lambda x \\
&=& - \lambda .\end{aligned}$$ Hence the eigenvalue $\lambda$
corresponding to $x$ is . $\Box$
